A tiny amount of Lamia's venom gets on Tucson's foot, but no more than just=
 at the toe, as he quickly registers the sound of venom being spat, just in=
 time to avoid getting an entire foot soaked with it.  It burns a hole thro=
ugh the metal, as he hobbles back just a slight.  He was prepared for such =
emergencies, as he cools the acid with a base like compound, from a finger =
jet coolant shooter, and cools the area right down, preventing further spre=
ad of the compound.

He hears Talon on the other end.   He manages to send =
her a silent com through the doorway.

"I'd do that but I'm not liking what=
's going in here.  I'm sorry but it's for your own protection.  What you ca=
n do, is get back to the others and inform them of my findings.  If I need =
backup I will inform all of you but for now, things are best left up to me.=
"

He keeps his audo and sonar systems at full volume, hearing every single=
 foot step made by his adversaries.  Although his wound had been neutralize=
d, it still left a trail of lubricant due to the minor damage sustained by =
Lamia's venom.  It hinders Tucson a slight but not enough to cause him to s=
urrender. In fact, quite the opposite as far as he was concerned.  Without =
giving any indication as to his intentions, he considers the idea of using =
his sonar systems differently than just pinpointing the enemy.  He had also=
 been able to disorient Decepticons by scrambling their navigational system=
s, causing them to get disorientated during flight.  It was an easy feat fo=
r him.  He hardly had to lift a finger to initiate the scrambling feature o=
f his sonar systems.

With a slightly more casual attitude, Tucson sighs, s=
hrugs, and without much on the line of body language, implements his sonar =
system and programs a scrambling frequency which only effects those in the =
room with him and no one outside the barrier.  He did not want to harm Talo=
n, Guardia, or Ravenchief, and knew it could cause them great discomfort if=
 he were to raise the wave length of the scrambler in their radius.  He kee=
ps his guard up and cross bow at the ready, just in case something were to =
go wrong.

"Hmmm, looks like someone doesn't know how to think outside the =
box."

If he played his cards right, Tucson wouldn't have to resort to viol=
ent actions against Nightstrike or Lamia.  He wanted to see them captured a=
nd brought to Lord Perseus for judgement.  He waits patiently to see if his=
 tactics work.

m Nightstrike and Lamia within the room. He picks up on foot steps, even th=
e most softest of steps. His audio sensors become his visuals, as he proces=
ses the information and moves according to the patterns of the sounds. Dark=
enss being the norm of his every day life, Tucson was neither bothered or u=
pset by it. Indeed if there was fun to be had, he was having a good time ri=
ght now, doing the job that Autobots were most famous for.
>

ing dirty.. That's just putting it mildly." 
> 
> He could hear that Nights=
trike had gotten himself a weapon once more, just by the tiny sounds that f=
ingers make when they click against the holster of their weapons or the cli=
cks of weapons themselves as they are prepared for combat. At the same time=
, with incredible swiftness, he loads up another six arrows in the cross bo=
w. With a casual gate, he walks into the next room, yet, being highly atten=
tive to the sounds around him. At the same time, his sonar systems were now=
 coming up with positive visuals of who was inside. They translate the wave=
s to heat readings thus turning them into thermal images, which his systems=
 quickly find matches for. He sends a com message back to Lord Perseus.
> 
=
> " I have a positive ID on the Hostiles in question. First one detected, i=
s identified as Nightstrike, who is apparently as adept in darkness as I am=
. Second hostile detected, is Lamia, not sure on their characteristics but =
I do have them as being hostile. Again these identifications are coming in =
through sonar and thermal reading systems, and they're known to be faulty. =
I'm sending these to you for confirmation of my findings. Normally I'm quit=
e sure of things but there are alot more signals flooding my sonars than I =
can keep up with, these two just happened to be the two I zeroed in most of=
 all."
> 
> His transmission is swift, and soon delivers the data to Perseu=
s. As soon as he transmits, he returns to focusing on the job at hand. Stop=
ping Nightstrike and Lamia. 
> 
> " Old junk.. Good one. You won't be sayin=
g that in a few astro seconds that's for sure." 
> 
> Tucson grows tired of=
 the charades that Nightstrike was playing. It was time to skunk him out co=
mpletely. He moves into the same room as Nightstrike and Lamia, and uses hi=
s sonar equipment to scan the schematics of the room. He finds just what he=
's looking for and slams a palm on the side of a revolving door, which now =
slams shut, including others leading into and out of the room, isolating hi=
mself with Nighstrike and Lamia.
> 
> " Let's hear you call me old junk now=
 Nightstrike. Oh yeah, I know who you are... I forgot to mention that my so=
nar systems double as an identication module.. And Lamia, I know you're in =
here somewhere too.. "
> 
> Even though he had pinpointed them, Tucson fire=
s no weapons and makes no moves to do any harm. As an Autobot he swore not =
to harm anyone unless they harmed him first. He keeps the doors shut and co=
ntinues the period of isolation until at least one of them came out into th=
e open. Not letting his guard down for one moment, he continues to scan the=
 room with sonar equipment and remains ready for anything.
